answer: A, B, C

The reversible spring-back behavior of the stent in event 13 is most directly accounted for by the demonstrations and explanations from events 10, 12, and 11. 

Event 10 demonstrates the superelastic response of nitinol wire, which is similar to the behavior observed in the stent. Even after extreme bending, the wire returns to its original form, contrasting with copper's plastic deformation. This directly relates to the reversible spring-back behavior of the stent.

Event 12 explains the superelasticity of nitinol at room temperature. When force is applied, the crystallites become rhombuses, and upon removing the force, they return to tidy squares, causing the wire to visually straighten again. This directly accounts for the reversible spring-back behavior of the stent.

Event 11 provides a structural explanation with diagrams and audible heating (~75Â°C) showing how the crystal structure shifts and then returns (twin structure reappears as it cools). This enables reversible deformation, which is consistent with the reversible spring-back behavior of the stent.
